channel.name: Passing Arbitrary Number Of Arguments To An @method

messages.content:
Good afternoon,

I am looking for a way for an `@method` to receive a variable amount of `Field` arguments as private input. I do not believe this is possible to do with varargs or an array of `Field`s, since  O1JS programs are compiled into fixed-size SNARK circuits, meaning that the arguments to its methods must also be of size. The current approach that I am considering now is the use of a struct with a high number of fields, and an a field specifying how many of the Field values are defined. This struct would then be used as an argument to `@method`.

The struct would look something like the following:

```
class FieldsArray extends Struct({
    values: [Field, Field, Field, Field, Field, Field, Field, Field, Field, Field, Field, Field, Field, Field, Field, Field]
    numFieldsDefined: Field
}
);
```

`FieldsArray` would be used as an argument to an `@method`. `values` contain the actual `Field`s that are passed into the `@mehtod` and `numFieldsDefined` specifies how many of the fields in the struct should be used in the `@method`, and this is what provides it with the `"varargs"` functionality.

I have the following questions:

* Is there a limit to the amount of `Field`s that I can include in the `FieldsArray`?
*  Is there a limit to the amount of `Field`s that I can include in the `FieldsArray`, so that it can be used as an argument to an `@method`?
* Is there a better way of achieving my goal?

Thank you very much.

you can also use Provable.array, i believe the limit of inputs has to do with the circuit size but i’ll let @gregor explain that since i dont actually remember/know.

the technique we use to do this is use dummies to populate the rest of the array, so if you have a fixed size of 100 fields but only use 2, then the remaining 98 is dummy Field(0). So if you sum up the entire array you end up with 1+1+0+0+…
but you always have to run your computation on the dummies as well, just make sure to discard it or so
Provable.if(dummy, oldResult, result)

Thank you for the answer! In my case, 0 is a valid value, so I would need to use a different sentinel value.

Do you happen to have some code examples exploring that?
you’ll have to pick a value thats obviously dummy, perhaps a struct { dummy: Bool, value: Field } would be enough
just use a merkle list and recursion
@maht0rz do you happen to have a code example? Thanks
@Las can you elaborate please?
let me draft one real quick
something like this should work but someone else should confirm

plus you need techniques to ensure you processed all the required non-dummies as necessary, e.g. non-dummy values submitted by the user.. e.g. by hashing all non-dummy values that should be processed and outputting a hash commitment that attests to the fact you processed them all properl
look up merkle tree
@maht0rz thanks, will look into it!
@Las I understand that, but how exactly?

api of a merkle tree operates basically like an array, you access leaves by an index, same as you would in an array. So if you want to treat your circuit state as an array it makes sense to use a merkle tree

Hmm, still not very clear how I would use that to allow for passing of arbitrary arguments. I'm currenly experimenting with recursion, but the documentation is not the cleanest in that part, and it appears that some code snippets are outdated

you can't pass arbitrary amounts or args to a circuit at any point, the 'arbitrary length' is acomplished by combining merkle tree 'as an array' and recursive circuits, so therefore you apply recursion as many times as you need to process elements, same as with the batch example above but with a merkle tree as the data structure behind it

My intuition here is tha the number of recursive calls actually fixes the length of the circuit. Now the challenge is to extract each value and build an array from it, which would only appear to be of a dynamic length, but in reality it's fixed by the dept of the provided recursive proof
Currently scraping GitHub for code samples of ZkProgram usage, let's see what comes out of this 👀
but what exactly isnt clear? how to write a zk program or how to compose zk programs recursively?
LOL, I posted a reply with a GitHub link and Discord blocked me on the desktop 🤣
discord is down rn
With recursion you can get dynamic length
Example which proves a chain of hashes of dynamic length: https://github.com/mitschabaude/o1js-offchain-state/blob/main/contracts/src/action-state-prover.ts

messages.content: @gregor so a recursive solution won’t work?
I’m currently developing a solution based on @maht0rz suggestion and approach
the snippet gregor shared shows a recursive zk program that allows you to process data of arbitrary length thanks to iterating over it 1 by 1 via recursion
Exactly 🙂 not sure where you got "it won't work" from @illya 😅
Oh, interesting! I thought since you said recursion can be of dynamic length, and ZK circuits need to know the size of all of the inputs, my intuition was flawed
I will check the code it in detail in a bit and write the feedback here
Looking at Gregor's example, it seems really similar, but maybe mine is more minimal as an example.
Wow, this is quite fascinating! Thank you for the resources @gregor and @45930. I'm going through them in detail and understanding what's going there. Will write back with an update.

It appears there was either a miscommunication issue or I'm misunderstanding something.

The core problem that I am trying to address is allowing a method of a smart contract to receive a variable amount of fields. Like a vararg. For example, the method can receive 3 or 300 arguments, and the method should be able to combine them into a collection and operate on each one of them individually.

A recursive approach was suggested by @Las. I began reasoning about a recursive approach to solve this problem, and wanted to investigate the idea wether it is possible to encode multiple values which can be obtained individually into a recursive proof. This would allow for using a recursive proof as a way of achieving the desired functionality of passing an arbitrary number of fields as an argument to a method. The model that I had for the solution is to build a recursive ZkProgram with a method that accepts a Field and a SelfProof. The method would be instructed to return a list, joined with the list returned by the proof:

class MySmartContract:
    @method add_argument(value: Field, proof_to_chain_to: MySmartContract.Proof):
        proof_to_chain_to.verify()
        existing_args: Array[Field] = proof_to_chain_to.value
        existing_args = existing_args.add(value)
        return existing_args

I later understood that the publicOutput of the method is linked to its return statement. That point was not very clear from documentation, but I could reverse-engineer it from the documentation. Since it is not possible to have a variable-sized data structure as a public output of a proof, a different approach had to be taken. I am considering using an encoding scheme which allows me to encode smaller integers into a 255bit one, but it would be too restrictive. I am still attempting with Recursive solutions, and learning the recursive API as I go.

By the way, am I understanding correctly that the go-to way to learning O1JS in depth is by reading the source code direcly? The documentation is a great start, but it does not go into detail, so I have currently opted for reading the implementation directly.
vararg doesn't make sense fundamentally
what is your logic

> The core problem that I am trying to address is allowing a method of a smart contract to receive a variable amount of fields.
This is strictly not possible.  What we're trying to help with is finding a workaround to support your use case without breaking the rules of a fixed circuit.

A common pattern is to replace "arbitrary number of inputs" with "fixed number of inputs called an arbitrary number of times" - does this pattern not work for you?

2 use cases I can imagine for var args are one named argument which is a list of variable length, or a variable number of named arguments, which represent flags or config for conditional logic.

For the first, we batch the variable length list into fixed-size chunks.  For the second, we split the method up into simple, non-branching methods.  In any case, you need to reduce complexity somehow so that every method has a fixed set of inputs.

> This is strictly not possible. What we're trying to help with is finding a workaround to support your use case without breaking the rules of a fixed circuit.
Thank you, I understand that. The solution would need to be creative.

> A common pattern is to replace "arbitrary number of inputs" with "fixed number of inputs called an arbitrary number of times" - does this pattern not work for you?
Possibly, I will think about that. Imagine the problem being as simple as a smart contract with an @method that accepts an array of Fields, sums their value and stores their sum in a state variable.
merkle list

@illya only thing thats missing in your current model is using hash lists, since the input/output is fixed size it can just be a hash.

therefore you can combine recursion and keep hashing and hashing until you attest you processed the entire data set you had to. You store the real values outside of the circuit and use hashing to collapse the data structure into a single hash.
accumulate sum in proof
@Las calls it a merkle list i call it a hashlist, probably the same. Merkle list is more likely the coreect name
Neither is correct
nonstandard nomenclature

smtn like this, keep appending hashes together like h(h(h(3),2),1) which gives you a merkle list root hash of all entries to process, your recursive proof will have that resulting hash as evidence of processing all the array entries
ofc pseudo code so may be broken
+ previousProcessedEntries must come from an earlier recursion proof, that is what makes each recursion step connected to the previous one

Thanks for the answers. This does allow summing them, but it does not allow me to operate on the collection of those items as a whole. For example, I cannot have access to all of the values passed as argument at the same time. For a more concrete example, I cannot pass an arbitray number of Fields to define a polygon.
the approach i described is like JS’s reduce, map or forEach, you can always work with one or multiple items in a batch

for your use case you can write a generic circuit method that iterates over an array of inputs, and then when constructing the ZkProgram generate 1000 variations of yiur method providing variable length of private input entries when defining the method
first one will have 2 inputs, then 3,4,5,6.. you can generate a large zk program using the same code and variable length of inputs between 0…100000
and then your users can create polygons up to 100k points in size 😄
ofc bear in mind circuit limits and at which point you might need recursion anyways
my question would be why do you need access to the entire polygon at once? why cant you process the polygon point by point?

I will run a ray casting algorithm on it. I need all points to be accessible.

Where can I learn more about generic circuits?
wtf
you can do this
but it will be hard

> Where can I learn more about generic circuits?
Not sure there's another place except docs.minaprotocol.com, but we're all happy to assist
read about ZKSNARKs in general
@illya What does it even mean to have "access to all values at the same time". Computers don't do that. They process one thing after another. Recursion allows you to do the same

Not sure what ray casting algorithm you want to run, but it sound like you don't need all points, you probably need only 2 consecutive points that form an edge. You can do that recursively by remembering the previous value as an accumulator.
Maybe you can share the pseudocode of what exactly you are trying to achieve.

@gregor what I mean by that is if I pass a list of the following fields [12, 124, 235, 235, 553], the method should have access to the full list of values in memory. Recursively, I'm only able to access one value from the output. If I accumulate the return values recursively, I don't foresee a way in which I'm able to return all of the values without accumulation.
do you need all or just a subset?
if you need all your circuit is still limited by circuit size
like with the batching example i’ve shared earlier you can recursively work on batches of points, like 50 points at a time or so depending on circuit complexity
Please note that the **polygon is defined by 3 or more points**. That's where the challenge is: allowing users to provide an arbitrary amount of Fields to the method/proof generator.

@maht0rz of course there's always a limit 🙂 The limit of the circuit size should be more than enough for any usage, specially because you can combine areas. I am actually basing the V1 of the solution on the code that you provided. Additionally, decomposing the math behind the ray casting, to allow to separate it into parts, and to separate arbitrary polygons into fixed-size polygons.
Thanks for all of the ongoing answers, this is very helpful!
Also this isn't checking the last edge created by first and last point, so keep in mind that you need to fix that as well.

Thank you. I am investigating your solution. I now have also another approach, which involves subdividing the polygons into arbitrary polygons, and then combining the proofs together to commit to a proof which is a combination of several smaller area proofs.

@Faserisko thank you for your code, it clarified a lot for me what you were talking about and how to approach this recursively. I have a follow-up question. From what I understand, your approach would require deploying an instance this ZK app for every individual proof of "point in Polygon" that I create, is my understanding correct?

No, can you elaborate how you got to that idea? With this code you can recursively prove the whole list of points and once you are finished, you can submit this proof to the zkapp where you can check if your point is in the polygon by checking the oddity of intersections. To check that it is indeed in the correct polygon you can also recursively accumulate some commitment to it (merkle list commitment) and expose it to the state so it will be the part of the public ouput.

So in the step function you will add something like
```
return {
  polygonCommitment: Posedion.hash([prevProof.publicOutput.polygonCommitment, currentPoint]),
...
```
You can share more of what you are actually trying to do so we can help further.
@illya Proof that you can do what you want: You can prove execution of WASM in SnarkyJS (theoretically)
sorry, O1JS

@Faserisko Thanks a lot! This gives it more clarify. I will be experimenting with the recursive approach in the next step. For now, I have settled for defining a polygon by using other polygons. I will write back with feedback, which will very likely take a couple of days.
@Las thank you, but I'm not questioning wether achieving the goal is possible. I'm looking for a concrete approach which will lead to the desired result.
